{{ extends 'global/Page.html' }} {{ block title }}Scenario Description{{ endblock }} {{ block content }}

In an effort to predict a characteristic of an object, an Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithm gets trained to make such predictions. For a given prediction problem, the AI algorithm has a binary output that indicates whether an object is going to have that characteristic of interest (positive) or not (negative). Either the positive or the negative characteristic can be present, and there are no other characterstics.

When the AI algorithm makes a correct prediction, we therefore differentiate between two outcomes:

  • True Positive (TP): the AI algorithm correctly predicts a positive characteristic, i.e., the absence of the negative characteristic.
  • True Negative (TN): the AI algorithm correctly predicts a negative characteristic, i.e., the absence of the positive characteristic.

Although being properly trained on this task, the AI algorithm is not entirely perfect and makes false predictions occasionally. Such false predictions, or misclassifications, can appear in two different flavors:

  • False Positive (FP): the AI algorithm predicts a positive characteristic but a negative characteristic is present.
  • False Negative (FN): the AI algorithm predicts a negative characteristic but a positive characteristic is present.

The following "confusion matrix" compares the predicted to the actual characteristics and summarizes the four outcomes introduced above.
